image.altText: A fire rages at night time, with trees burning.

props.synopsis: A fire raging near Mount Dandenong overnight destroys one home and damages another, with authorities residents to remain on alert as about 200 firefighters continue to battle the blaze.

title.children: One home lost as firefighters battle bushfire in Melbourne's east

image.altText: A small boat heads towards a turbine in the ocean.

props.synopsis: Offshore wind faces community and political opposition as well support for its promise of ample renewable energy and while some claims can be ruled out, experts say other concerns are valid.

title.children: Do offshore turbines kill whales? Wind farm facts, fiction and unknowns

image.altText: A photo of a woman on display at a rally in Melbourne

props.synopsis: As Australians across the country rally to call for greater funding and legal change to stop violence against women, organiser Sherele Moody calls out men for not doing enough.

title.children: Rallies call for more government funding to end violence against women

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair wears a white cap and shirt and rests her chin on her hand, looking off camera in a park, smiling.

props.synopsis: As running clubs soared in popularity after the pandemic, Ash, a non-runner, struggled to find her own community — so she started a walking club.

title.children: 'It's so much harder to meet people': The walking club helping women connect

image.altText: Lots of round cactus fronds

props.synopsis: Noxious weeds cost Australia billions of dollars each year in agricultural and environmental degradation. These weeds of national significance are among the worst.

title.children: There are 32 weeds of national significance. Here are 10 of the worst

image.altText: Police stand at a crime scene in the evening.

props.synopsis: A 24-year-old man dies in hospital after police say he was stabbed during a fight in the suburb of Lyndhurst on Friday night.

title.children: Man, 24, dies after being stabbed during fight in Melbourne's south-east

image.altText: A diptych compiling three screenshots showing extensive damage at a social housing estate.

props.synopsis: Amid a housing crisis, a social housing complex in Melbourne's south-east sits empty for more than six months — and was broken into and vandalised — after residents were suddenly relocated to make way for a redevelopment.

title.children: Tenants were moved out of their homes. Then the dwellings sat empty for months

image.altText: A black and white cat sits on a fence post in front of rolling hills

props.synopsis: For thousands of years farmers have kept cats for their talents at catching rats and mice, and now there are calls for people working the land to be able to claim tax deductions their health and upkeep,

title.children: Working dogs are famous but what about working cats?

image.altText: An archival photo of Maria Langley aged 18. She's got curly hair, a neckalce and a 19th century victorian era dress,

props.synopsis: An unmarked grave, believed to belong to a murdered mother and child, has been found in a cemetery survey, ending a 100-year-old mystery.

title.children: Grave hunter helps family find believed burial site of murdered relatives

image.altText: Oscar Piastri driving his F1 car through pit lane, with spectators watching

props.synopsis: Australia hosts the opening race of the 2025 Formula 1 season — a championship that is one of the most anticipated in recent years. Here is what you need to know about the Australian Grand Prix.

title.children: F1 Australian Grand Prix: How to watch and what time the race starts

image.altText: The words ‘No Change To WA GST’ have been scrawled on a reporter's arm and signed by Anthony Albanese.

props.synopsis: For the first time, Victoria shifts to become a relative beneficiary in a new carve-up of the GST, and will receive a "significant" $3.7 billion increase to its GST take.

title.children: Victoria tips from 'giver' to 'taker' in GST carve-up with $3.7b boon

image.altText: a photo of two guys at the top of a mountain after a hike overlooking ocean

props.synopsis: The release on bail of two Bendigo teenagers charged with 13 assault-related offences has left their alleged victims fearing for their safety.

title.children: Mates allegedly bashed in Bendigo say they are not comforted by bail changes

image.altText: A young female racing driver leaning on her car, holding her helmet, looking in the distance

props.synopsis: As one of the two inaugural Aussies on the grid in the all-female racing category, Aiva Anagnostiadis wants to be an example for other young girls who dream of driving fast.

title.children: Aiva only has a learners licence, but is inspiring young girls to go fast

image.altText: Sam Landsberger looking at the camera.

props.synopsis: The driver will have his licence suspended for two and a half years after refusing a blood test, following a crash that killed sports journalist Sam Landsberger.

title.children: Driver sentenced over drug test refusal in crash that killed Melbourne journalist

image.altText: A table of machetes

props.synopsis: Experts say a machete ban and tougher laws could reduce knives on the street, but that there’s limited data on whether it will curb knife-related violence.

title.children: Victoria is cracking down on knife crime. Will it work?

image.altText: Trees along a riverbank.

props.synopsis: As one end of the country contends with the fallout from ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred, another part of Australia is battling the opposite conditions. Hopes that water will make its way south are evaporating fast, with experts saying conditions are too dry.

title.children: Little hope for ex-cyclone flows in NSW, Victoria and SA, experts warn

image.altText: A man leans on a fence looking into a fenced off area, the word 'scabs' is spelt out in coffee cups through the fence

props.synopsis: The 1998 waterfront dispute was one of the most significant industrial disputes in Australia, but what happened to those who were recruited to keep the wharves running?

title.children: From 'scabs' to unemployed: The recruits caught up in the waterfront dispute

image.altText: Part of a retaining wall sitting on soil that has slid away.

props.synopsis: Some residents who were forced to evacuate their homes following a landslide in January are still locked out of their properties due to ongoing safety risks, and they've been dealt another blow after being targeted by thieves.

title.children: Mornington Peninsula properties 'ransacked' after being evacuated due to landslide

image.altText: woman wearing blue scarf and husband with his arm around her shoulders both smiling at camera

props.synopsis: As Australians shake their heads at the prospect of another increase in power prices, this Victorian couple have gone green with their home and business and won't pay an energy bill for years.

title.children: No power bill for 'next 10 years' as couple takes whole life off-grid

image.altText: Jamarra Ugle-Hagan playing for the Western Bulldogs against the Sydney Swans.

props.synopsis: Jamarra Ugle-Hagan has trained sparingly in recent weeks, but Bulldogs coach Luke Beveridge can't say when he'll be fully back in the fold as he continues to work through personal issues.

title.children: 'Too much uncertainty': Mystery continues to surround Bulldogs star's availability

image.altText: Serious man crossing his arms in front of a pile of rubbish, wears cap, tattoos on both arms, beard.

props.synopsis: Residents living along the housing growth corridor between Bacchus Marsh and Melbourne's western fringe say illegal rubbish dumping has become a problem of "epidemic proportions".

title.children: In Melbourne's west, rubbish dumping has hit 'epidemic proportions'

image.altText: A man with a face mask on.

props.synopsis: A 91-year-old Victorian woman thought she was handing her bank card over for protection from fraudulent charges, but it was a scam.

title.children: Police launch search after $130,000 stolen from elderly woman

image.altText: A pink and purple drawing of a boy sitting down in court, arms folded.

props.synopsis: Amy says she has not slept in six months, waiting for a knock on the door to learn her 15-year-old son's been injured, or worse.

title.children: Mother welcomes new Victorian bail laws to help her son

image.altText: A police officer, an ATO officer and a Border Force agent look out over a large tobacco crop.

props.synopsis: Police say the destruction of 5.2 hectares of illicit tobacco at a northern Victorian property will significantly impact the booming black market.

title.children: $35m worth of illegal tobacco up in smoke after huge crops seized

image.altText: Woman posed for a photoin nature, wearing a patterned dress

props.synopsis: Deanne Mathews, a self-described "healer and mentor", pleads guilty to drug trafficking after serving magic mushrooms to a woman who died at a Victorian health retreat.

title.children: 'Healer' who served mushroom drink to woman who died pleads guilty to drug charge

image.altText: Police cars on rural road

props.synopsis: Gippsland veterinarian Vivian Stockil is sentenced to more than two years in prison for dangerous driving causing the death of cyclist Leslie Camilleri.

title.children: Vet who checked phone before fatal collision with cyclist jailed

image.altText: A woman and a child sit next to each other in a theatre

props.synopsis: A Victorian theatre company is letting audiences know when lights will flash or music will change abruptly or how people might react during certain moments.

title.children: Theatre group's additions help put neurodivergent audiences at ease

image.altText: A young man with dark hair and a beard stands outside a house in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: The former retail worker in Melbourne says the tech giant told him to stop wearing a pro-Palestinian necklace and bracelet because the jewellery made other employees and customers feel "unsafe" and "unwelcome".

title.children: Worker accuses Apple of discrimination over jewellery supporting Gaza

image.altText: Two police officers

props.synopsis: Premier Jacinta Allan promises to "jolt the system" by banning machetes and enacting tougher bail laws for both young and adult offenders in the face of growing crime rates.

title.children: 'We got it wrong': Victorian premier launches sweeping changes to bail laws

image.altText: Large boxes of illegal cigarettes at a warehouse in Melbourne

props.synopsis: Health Minister Mark Butler was in Melbourne on Wednesday to announce about $160 million in extra funds in an effort to stamp out the rampant illicit tobacco trade.

title.children: Federal government announces extra $160m to fight illegal cigarette trade

image.altText: A teenage girl whose face is pixelated lies in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: Kmart is investigating the incident and the 13-year-old girl's mother hopes her story will alert other parents to the potential dangers of products used by young people.

title.children: Kmart pulls skincare product after teen hospitalised with eye pain

image.altText: Orange scooters parked on a footpath in front of a bayside view.

props.synopsis: The City of Yarra has voted to increase e-scooter permit fees from $1 to $5 per day, with companies saying the fee hike makes their operation unsustainable.

title.children: Company says 400pc fee hike could end e-scooters hire in this Melbourne council

image.altText: Man wearing a beanie smiles.

props.synopsis: Glenn Ernest Fenwick, 61, was jailed for a maximum of five and a half years after pleading guilty to the manslaughter of Christopher Jarvis, with the judge labelling the killing "brutal, unlawful and dangerous conduct".

title.children: Man sentenced over 'brutal' 2006 killing of Christopher Jarvis

image.altText: Smiling Indian woman in front of white and pink wall of flowers, wears pink and white saree, pearl and silver necklace, earings.

props.synopsis: One year after Point Cook mother Chaithanya Madhagani's body was found in a wheelie bin, her friends are still waiting for answers.

title.children: 'What are the police doing?': Questions over Melbourne mum's death
